skills.name: Order decimals with the same number of digits
Use inequality notation to order decimals with a different number of digits

explanations.A: Not quite, perhaps you have chosen this because 62 is bigger than 8. Place a 0 after the 0.8 - now both numbers have the same amount of digits after the decimal point. Which has the greatest amount of hundredths?
explanations.B: Not quite, this symbol means that the two numbers are equal to each other. Try using an inequality symbol.
explanations.C: 0.8 is 80 hundredths, which is greater than 0.62, 62 hundredths.
explanations.D: Not quite, this symbol means that the two numbers are completely equivalent to each other. Try using an inequality symbol.

explanations.A: 0.71 is 71 hundredths, which is less than than 0.9 (90 hundredths).
explanations.B: Not quite, this symbol means that the two numbers are completely equivalent to each other. Try using an inequality symbol.
explanations.C: Not quite, perhaps you have chosen this because 71 is bigger than 9. Place a 0 after the 0.9 - now both numbers have the same amount of digits after the decimal point. Which has the greatest amount of hundredths?
explanations.D: Not quite, this symbol means that the two numbers are equal to each other. Try using an inequality symbol.

explanations.A: It looks as if you've picked the first number from the list. We're looking for the smallest number from the list.
explanations.B: It looks as if you may have picked the greatest value and not the smallest.
explanations.C: It looks as if you may have looked at the last digit, seen its a 0 and thought it's the smallest. However, we need to consider the tenths column too.
explanations.D: This has zero units, zero tenths and 9 hundredths. It is the smallest number.

explanations.A: It looks as if you've picked the first number from the list. We're looking for the smallest number from the list.
explanations.B: It looks as if you may have picked the greatest value and not the smallest.
explanations.C: This has zero units, zero tenths and 8 hundredths. It is the smallest number.
explanations.D: It looks as if you may have looked at the last digit, seen it's a 0 and thought that it's the smallest. However, we need to consider the tenths column too.

explanations.A: The diagram is split into 100 equal parts so each part is worth 0.01 not 0.1...
explanations.B: This would represent 0.8 but we are looking for a diagram that shows a decimal GREATER THAN 0.8
explanations.C: We are looking for a diagram showing a number greater than 0.8. This diagram is split into 100 equal parts so each part is worth 0.01 not 0.1...
explanations.D: The diagram is split into 100 equal pieces and 90 of these pieces are shaded, that gives the fraction 90/100 which when simplified is 0.9 - a decimal greater than 0.8!

explanations.A: This would represent 0.7 but we are looking for a diagram that shows a decimal GREATER THAN 0.7
explanations.B: The diagram is split into 100 equal pieces and 80 of these pieces are shaded, that gives the fraction 80/100 which when simplified is 0.8 - a decimal greater than 0.7!
explanations.C: This would represent 0.27 but we are looking for a diagram that shows a decimal GREATER THAN 0.7
explanations.D: We are looking for a diagram showing a number greater than 0.7. This diagram is split into 100 equal parts so each part is worth 0.01 not 0.1...

explanations.A: To find the biggest number, compare the units place value column of each...
explanations.B: Comparing the units place value column, we see that this number has 1 and all the others have 0 therefore 1.2 is the biggest number!
explanations.C: To find the biggest number, compare the units place value column of each...
explanations.D: 9 is the highest digit but that does not make this number the biggest. Compare the units place value column, what do you notice?

explanations.A: To find the biggest number, compare the units place value column of each...
explanations.B: 8 is the highest digit but that does not make this number the biggest. Compare the units place value column, what do you notice?
explanations.C: Comparing the units place value column, we see that this number has 1 and all the others have 0 therefore 1.1 is the biggest number!
explanations.D: To find the biggest number, compare the units place value column of each...

explanations.A: More digits does not mean a higher value. We need to look for a number with a value greater than 2 in the units or a 2 in the units and a value greater than 3 in the tenths...
explanations.B: I think you might have compared the tenths and forgotten to compare the units. We need to look for a number with a value greater than 2 in the units or a 2 in the units and a value greater than 3 in the tenths...
explanations.C: 2.3 and 2.30 have the same value! We need to look for a number with a value greater than 2 in the units or a 2 in the units and a value greater than 3 in the tenths...
explanations.D: Because we have 2.3 < _ we are looking for a number greater than 2.3. 2.4 is larger as it is 2 wholes and 4 tenths rather than 2 wholes and 3 tenths!

explanations.A: Because we have 3.8 < _ we are looking for a number greater than 3.8. 3.9 is larger as it is 3 wholes and 9 tenths rather than 3 wholes and 8 tenths!
explanations.B: 3.8 and 3.80 have the same value! We need to look for a number with a value greater than 3 in the units or a 3 in the units and a value greater than 8 in the tenths...
explanations.C: I think you might have compared the tenths and forgotten to compare the units. We need to look for a number with a value greater than 3 in the units or a 3 in the units and a value greater than 8 in the tenths...
explanations.D: More digits does not mean a higher value. We need to look for a number with a value greater than 3 in the units or a 3 in the units and a value greater than 8 in the tenths...
